sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When was the other time you ſpeak of?

sp.speaker: Sir Edward Southcoat.
sp.p: I remember him there one Thurſday, up 〈…〉 the Bowling-green at Tixhall, where there was a particular Company.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, We deſire to know, when his Brother did buy the Horſe of Mr. Ireland?

sp.speaker: Sir Edward Southcoat.
sp.p: When we came back; for he came home with us from my Lord Aſtons, and we began our Journey, the 9th. or 10th. of September, from Tixhall to Kingſton; and when we arriv'd at my Fathers Houſe, my Brother bought the Horſe of him.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you come home back again with Mr. Ireland, do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Sir Edw. Southcoat.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, we did.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When did you ſet out from Tixhall?

sp.speaker: Sir Edw. Southcoat
sp.p: The Ninth of September, my Lord, I think it was; I am ſure, it was upon a Monday, the Ninth or Tenth.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When did you come home?

sp.speaker: Sir. Edw. Southcoat.
sp.p: We were Four Days on our Journey.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And did you come ſtraight to London?

sp.speaker: Sir Edw. Southcoat.
sp.p: No, we went to my Father's Houſe in Surry.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Which way did you come?

sp.speaker: Sir Edw. Southcoat.
sp.p: The Firſt Night we came to the Bull in Coventry; and from thence, the next Night, we went to the Altar-Stone at Banbury; and from Banbury, we came the Third Day to Agmondiſhman (I think, it is called,) a little Town in Buckinghamſhire: And from thence, the Fourth Day, to my Father's Houſe, by Kingſton in Surry.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And then Ireland ſold his Brother his Horſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How long was he at your Father's Houſe in Surry, Sir Edward?

sp.speaker: Sir Edw. Southcoat.
sp.p: My Lord, we came on the Thurſday; and, as I take it, he went on the Saturday to London. My Brother, after he had bought his Horſe, lent him the Horſe to Town; and ſent a Man with him, to bring it back again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: That Saturday, my Lord, makes it come juſt to the Fourteenth of September; and is the very Day Fortnight before Michaelmas-Day.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to ask this Gentleman, Whether he ſaw Ireland all Auguſt, and till the Fourteenth of September, in Staffordſhire, and elſewhere? and, How long in Staffordſhire.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw. Southcoat.
sp.p: I cannot ſay, as to any particular Days of the Months, after our Coming from Holy-Well, till our Coming from Tixhall to London.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Marry, if he did, he would contradict what he had ſaid before: For from the time of Coming from Holy-Well, to the time of Coming back to London, he could tell but of Two Days, and thoſe uncertain: For he remembers not by the Times, but by other particular Circumſtances.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, be pleaſed to ask him this Queſtion, When was the Firſt Day he ſaw him in September?

sp.speaker: Sir Edw. Southcoat.
sp.p: Truly, my Lord, I remember not any Day before we began our Journey home?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But, my Lord, this is his Teſtimony: He was in his Company till the Sixteenth of Auguſt. It is true, there were other times, that he ſaw him at Tixhall; but he cannot particularly ſpeak unto them: But by and by, we ſhall go on to every Day, and prove particularly where he was.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know, Was Sir Edward Southcoat at the Tryal of Ireland a Witneſs, or no?

sp.speaker: Sir Edw. Southcoat.
sp.p: No, I was not, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Were you at Whitebread's Tryal, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Edw. Southcoat.
sp.p: Yes, I was, and gave the ſame Evidence I give now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then ſwear Mr. John Southcoat. (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: This is Sir Edward Southcoat's Brother, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What, he that bought the Horſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I bought the Horſe of Mr. Ireland.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, what do you ask him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, When did you meet Mr. Ireland in Auguſt 1678? And where?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p:
My Lord, I met with Mr. Ireland upon Monday the Fifth of Auguſt, at the Bull-inn in St. Albans, with my Lord Aſton: I came thither that Day with my Father 〈◊〉 Mother. And the next Day we went to Northampton; and there we Inn'd at the Sign of the George, Sir William Farmer's Houſe; which is an Houſe in the Road, us'd for an Inn ſince the Town was burnt: And I convers'd with him every Day, in our Journey. And from thence, the next Day, we went to Coventry, to the Bull-Inn there; and from thence, to my Lord Aſtons (on Thurſday-Night) at Tixhall: There we ſtay'd all Fryday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday. Mr. Ireland was there; I was with him all the while. And then upon Tueſday we ſet out for Holy-Well in Flintſhire; and went that Night to Nantwich, to the Lamb there. And the
next Day we went through Cheſter to Holy-Well▪ We ſtay'd that Night at Holy-Well; and the next Day, came back again towards Noon, to Cheſter; and there lay that Night: And then the next Night, which was Fryday, we came back again to Tixhall.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was Mr. Ireland with you both thoſe Journeys, all the while?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he was; I did ſee him, and rode with him every Day.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, How long were you at Tixhall, after you came from Holy-Well?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: We ſtay'd there till we came away for good and all.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Just.
sp.p: Was Mr. Ireland with you all that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: No, he was not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember, that Mr. Ireland came to Tixhall the Ninth of September; and came along home with you, when you came?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: Yes, I do remember it very well.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What Day did you come home, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: We came home in Four days.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: When did he leave you?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: We came home upon Thurſday, and he went to London on Saturday.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, Can you recollect when you did firſt 〈◊〉 him again at Tixhall, after you came from Holy-Well?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot tell particularly any day, till the day we came away.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Do you remember the Horſe Match between Mr. Chetwine, and Sir Henry Gough?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: I was there, my Lord; but I do not remember, Mr. Ireland was there.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How long did he ſtay at your Father's Houſe in Gurry, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: Two Days, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: You lent him your Horſe you bought of him, I think, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: Yes, up to London I did; and I ſent my Man with him, to bring him back again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Has Mr. Oats any Queſtions to ask this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to ask Mr. Southcoat, Whether or no he is ſure, that Ireland was in his Company from the Fifth of Auguſt, to the Sixteenth?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: Yes, every Day, I am ſure of it; I remember it very well.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, ask him, Whether or no he teſtifyed this that he now ſwears, at Ireland's Tryal?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: My Lord, I was not at Ireland's Tryal?

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Then I deſire to ask him, Whether or no he did teſtify this, at the Five Jeſuite's Tryal?

sp.speaker: Mr. John Southcoat.
sp.p: No I was not ſent for to any of the Tryals.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: I am ſorry you were not, Sir: 'Twas pity you were not there. It might have ſav'd ſome Innocent Blood.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Now ſwear Harriſon. (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, will you give an Account, when you ſaw Ireland, and where.

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: In the Year of our Lord 1678. my Maſter Sir John Southcoat, went with my Lady, on Monday the Fifth of Auguſt, to St. Albans; and we came with a Coach, and Four Horſes: For my Maſter-had an old Servant, that had a pair of Horſes, which my Maſter made uſe of. And there we met my Lord Aſton, in the Company of Mr. Ireland. And the next Morning, my Lord Aſton went with my Maſter and Lady towards Tixhall: And I rode by, in Mr. Ireland's Company; and came acquainted with him that Day. That Night we came to Northampton; and there we Inn'd at a Stone-Houſe, that was us'd for the Inn, the Town being burnt before. The next Night we went to Coventry; and on Thurſday we came to Tixhall: there we ſtay'd till Tueſday. After when we went to Holy-Well; and the Tueſday-Night we lay at Natwich. And thence we went to Holy-Well, and ſtay'd there on Wedneſday Night: And on Thurſday we came to Weſt Cheſter; and I parted with him upon the Fryday at Weſt-Cheſter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, did you know this Ireland? Was it he, that was Tryed and Executed?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: I was at Mr. Ireland's Tryal.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was it the ſame man that was Tryed?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſaw him at his Tryal, the hair of his face was grown, and he was a little diſordered; he did not look ſo well, becauſe he was not ſo well dreſs'd; but it was the ſame man, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Before this Man goes, we have more queſtions to ask him: When did you ſee him again, after you left him in Cheſter you ſay?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: I ſaw him ſeveral times at Tixhall; I ſaw him at the Bowling-green upon a Thurſday; and I ſaw him when the Horſe-Race was between Mr. Chetwin, and Sir Henry Gough; I cannot tell what day it was; for I had no reaſon to keep an account of the particular dayes at that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you come up with your Maſter again the 9th. of September?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: My Lord, I did ſo, I have a Note wherein I ſet down the charges at that time. It is in this bit of paper, which I have kept in my Almanack ever ſince. My Lord Aſton ſent his Coach with us to Banbury, where my Maſters Coach was to meet him; but came only to Conventry the firſt night. The next Night, which was Tueſday, we came to the Altar-Stone at Banbury, and there we lay: From thence on Wedneſday, we came to Agmondiſham, where we were Ill Lodged. The next day we baited at Ʋxbridge, and came to Kingſton, and ſo to Sir John Southcoat's Houſe upon the Thurſday night. Upon the Fryday, Mr. Ireland ſold his Horſe to Mr. John Southcoat, my Maſters Son. Upon the Saturday morning, I came with him from my Maſters Houſe towards London; he did ride upon the Horſe he had ſold to Mr. Southcoat, and ſo we came up to Town, and took Water; and I took a little bagg that belonged to Mr. Ireland upon my arm, and we landed at Somerſet-Houſe, and I came with him to his Lodging in Ruſſel-ſtreet; and when he came there, he went up ſtairs, where were two Women met him, and welcom'd him home: Said they, We are glad you are come, we thought we had loſt you, becauſe we had never heard from you all this while. There I took my leave of him, and did not ſee him again till his Tryal at the Old-Baily, and this was Saturday the 14th. of September.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Pray let me ſee your paper you ſpeak of. (Which was delivered in, and the Court look't upon it.)

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you write this in your Journey?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I did write it at that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Are the particular dayes inſerted there, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: No, they are not, Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: I could not write well, it was only but Memorandums for my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What day of the Month was the Saturday he came to Town?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: It was the 14th. of September, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: That agrees with all that the Women ſaid, that he came on Saturday a fortnight before Michaelmas, being the ſame day of the Week as Michaelmas-day was: Thus far it is as clear as the Sun at Noon-day.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: My Lord, There was a time, when this was not believ'd.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Oats, we know there was a time, when there were Ignoramus Juries, and things were believed, and not believed, as the humour went. What can you Mr. Oats, ſay to it? I muſt needs tell you, Prima Facie, 'Tis ſo ſtrong an Evidence, that if you have any ſenſe in the World, you muſt be concern'd at it.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Not at all, my Lord; I know who they are, and what is the end of it all.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Upon my Faith, I have ſo much Charity for you, as my fellow-Creature, as to be concerned for you.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: 'Tis not two ſtraws matter, whether you be or no; I know my own Innocency.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Thou art the moſt obſtinately hardened Wretch, that ever I ſaw.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, ask him, whether he did not appear at Mr. Ireland's Tryal? and let it be remembred what Credit he had then, for all this ſtory he tells now. Theſe People come here to ſerve a turn only, and care not what they ſwear againſt me.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You muſt hold your Tongue.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: My Lord. I muſt ſpeak the truth, and I will ſpeak the truth.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: I think, there is ſcarce a word of Truth comes out of thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p:
You may think what you will, my Lord; But theſe Popiſh Traytors, I am ſure,
will ſwear any thing, and ſubborn Witneſſes upon Witneſſes againſt me, and to overthrow the Plot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Withins.
sp.p: If you cannot behave your ſelf better than you do, we muſt ſend you elſewhere; we muſt not ſuffer this Behaviour: And therefore either be quiet, or get you gone.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Let him keep himſelf in order, and we'll hear him. If he think by Boiſterous Impudency to out-face Juſtice, we will not ſuffer it. Go on, Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. George Hobſon. (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Were you in the Journey to Tixhall with Mr. Ireland and my Lord Aſton in 78?

sp.speaker: Hobſon.
sp.p: Yes, I was ſo, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray tell all your Knowledg of that matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobſon.
sp.p: From the 3d. of Auguſt till the 16th. at night, I was preſent with him every day.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How do you know you were?

sp.speaker: Hobſon.
sp.p: That is to ſay, the 3d. of Auguſt he came to my Lord's Houſe at Standen in Hartfordſhire in the Evening, and there he remained till Monday the 5th. of August; and that day in the morning, he went together with other Company, to St. Albans, where we met Sir John Southcoat, and his Lady towards the Evening; and we all Lodged there, becauſe that was the appointed place to meet at: We Lodged the 6th. of Auguſt at night at Northampton; upon the 7th. at Coventry; upon the 8th. at Tixhall, my Lord's Houſe, where Mr. Ireland remain'd till Tueſday the 13th. in the Morning. And upon the 13th. in the morning, we ſet forth with my Lady Aſton, my Lord's Mother, and Sir John Southcoat, and Mr. Ireland, and the other Company, towards a place called Holy-Well in Flintſhire: That night, being Tueſday the 13th. of Auguſt, we Lodged at Nantwich in Cheſhire; the Wedneſday night we Lodged at Holy-well, where Mr. Ireland was with the reſt of the Company; and on Thurſday night we returned back again to Cheſter; and lay there. Upon Friday we came back again to my Lord's Houſe at Tixhall. After that I did not ſee Mr. Ireland till Monday the 26th, of Auguſt, when he came back again to our Houſe: Where he went in the mean time, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Whoſe Houſe is it, that this man means by our Houſe?

sp.speaker: Hobſon.
sp.p: I mean my Lord Aſton's Houſe at Tixhall.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You knew him very well, did not you?

sp.speaker: Hobſon.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I knew him very well.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You ſay, he came back the 26th. of Auguſt to Tixhall.

sp.speaker: Hobſon.
sp.p: Yes, as I remember, he did ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How long after the 26th. of Auguſt was it, that you ſaw him at Tixhall?

sp.speaker: Hobſon.
sp.p: When he went away for London.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Hobſon.
sp.p: The 9th. of September.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you come a long with him to London?

sp.speaker: Hobſon.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I ſee him go; he was not in the Coach, but he was in the Company.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: My Lord, I would fain ask him a queſtion, When he was firſt acquainted with Mr. Ireland, that he ſpeaks of?

sp.speaker: Hobſon.
sp.p: I never ſaw him till he came to my Lord Astons at Standen.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Were you at the Tryal of Mr. Ireland, Sir?

sp.speaker: Hobſon.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I was not; I was then in Staffordſhire.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Then it is material my Lord, for me to ask him this Queſtion, it relating to a particular Perſon; whether Ireland that was Executed, was the Ireland he ſaies he was with?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: I will ask him, if you will. Was that the ſame man that was afterwards Tryed and Executed?

sp.speaker: Hobſon.
sp.p: I believe it was; my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: I inſiſt not ſo much upon the queſtion, but only in reference to the Witneſs; his acquaintance being ſo ſhort with him.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Truly I think it is not ſo very ſhort; for he ſwears he was with him from the 3d. of Auguſt till the 16th. every day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Withins.
sp.p: I have no great Acquaintance with you; but I know you, Mr. Oats, becauſe I have ſeen you ſo often.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Is it the ſame Ireland that was at the Tryal? You Harriſon, you ſaw him then?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: The very ſame, and no other.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Withins.
sp.p: Certainly, no Body doubts that.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: 'Tis fit he ſhould have his Queſtion anſwer'd, if the Witneſs can. Pray go on, Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear George North. (Which was done.) Pray, Will you give an Account, where you met Mr. Ireland, and whether you were with him in his Journey?

sp.speaker: North.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſaw him the Fourth of Auguſt, which was Sunday, at Standen, my Lord Aſton's Houſe in Hartfordſhire: Upon the Fifth, he went with my Lord to St. Albans; where my Lord met with Sir John Southcoat, and his Lady: and I was with them. And from thence we went on Tueſday, to the George at Northampton: And from thence, on Wedneſday the Seventh, to the Bull at Coventry. And upon the Eighth, we came to Tixhall, which was Thurſday. And from Thurſday the Eighth, to Tueſday the Thirteenth, I did ſee him every Day at my Lord's Houſe at Tixhall.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Whither went he then?

sp.speaker: North.
sp.p: He went with my old Lady, and ſome other Company, to go to Holy-Well.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When did you ſee him again?

sp.speaker: North.
sp.p: I did ſee him ſeveral times after that at Tixhall: But I took no particular Notice of him again, till he went away for London.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: North.
sp.p: I did ſee him the Ninth of September. He came to go with Sir John. Southcoat to London: Mr. John Southcoat, and he. I took my Leave of him.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: What Religion are you of, Sir?

sp.speaker: North.
sp.p: I am a Catholick, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: I deſire to know, how he comes to remember this ſo well?

sp.speaker: North.
sp.p: I waited at the Table; and he was every Day at Dinner with my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Were you at the Tryal of Ireland a Witneſs?

sp.speaker: North.
sp.p: No indeed, my Lord, I was not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Richard Ingletrap. (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, will you give an Account, whether you knew Mr. Ireland? and where you ſaw him?

sp.speaker: Ingletrap.
sp.p: The Firſt of Auguſt, my Lord, I was ordered to be at Standen in Hartfordſhire, to wait upon my Lord Aſton, to go with him to Tixhall. And the Third of Auguſt, I ſaw Mr. Ireland there at Standen-Lodge at my Lord's Houſe. The Fourth Day he reſted there, being Sabbath-Day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What are you, an Hackney-Coach-man?

sp.speaker: Ingletrap.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I am ſo. And upon the Fifth, which was Monday, he went with my Lord Aſton to St. Albans; upon the Sixth, to Northampton; on the Seventh, to Coventry; and the Eighth day, to Tixhall-Lodge. He was in the Company, and went all the way with him; and I was there too.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How long did he ſtay there?

sp.speaker: Ingletrap.
sp.p: Till Tueſday the 13th.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you ſee him there till Tueſday?

sp.speaker: Ingletrap.
sp.p: I do not ſay, That I did ſee him every Day.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you go with them on Tueſday to Holy-Well?

sp.speaker: Ingletrap.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But, my Lord, you obſerve, that is paſt one of the Times, that he ſwore Ireland was here in Town; that is, between the Eighth and Twelfth of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: It is ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, what Religion are you of, Mr. Ingletrap?

sp.speaker: Ingletrap.
sp.p: I am a Proteſtant, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Were you at the Tryal of the Five Jeſuites, or that of Ireland?

sp.speaker: Ingletrap.
sp.p: No, I was not.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire you would ask him, he being a Proteſtant, How he came to be acquainted with Ireland, that was a Prieſt?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Oats, Is there no Converſation to be between Papiſts and Proteſtants?

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Truly very little, my Lord: But that is not to the Point now. I deſire to have an Anſwer to my Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Ingletrap.
sp.p: There was no great Acquaintance between us, my Lord; for I never ſaw him before that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Andrew Wetton. (Which was done.) Did you go that Journey with my Lord Aſton to Tixhall?

sp.speaker: Wetton.
sp.p: No. I went from Tixhall to Holy-Well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What Day did you ſet out from Tixhall?

sp.speaker: Wetton.
sp.p: Upon Tueſday the Thirteenth of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Where did you lie that Night?

sp.speaker: Wetton.
sp.p: At Nantwich, at the Holy-Lamb. And the next Day we baited at Cheſter: and from thence we came, the next Night, to Holy-Well: There we ſtay'd all Night, and till next Day at Noon. We din'd at Holy-Well, and came that Night back to Choſter: And from thence, the next Day, we came home to Tixhall.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was Mr. Ireland there all the while?

sp.speaker: Wetton.
sp.p: Mr. Ireland was there, I look't after his Horſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When did he come firſt to Tixhall?

sp.speaker: Wetton.
sp.p: He came upon the Eighth, and ſtay'd till the Thirteenth; and then went to Holy-Well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, what Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Wetton.
sp.p: I am a Proteſtant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And the Ninth of September he came away from Tixhall for London, you ſay?

sp.speaker: Wetton.
sp.p: Yes. I ſaw them take Coach, and he did ride on Horſe-back.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you ſee him often at Tixhall, between the time he came from Holy-Well, and the time he went to London?

sp.speaker: VVetton.
sp.p: Yes, he was there ſeveral times; but I cannot tell the particular Days: But, my Lord, if you pleaſe, I can tell you the very Money he gave me, which was a Shilling, and two Six Pences, when we came back from Holy-Well.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And the Sixteenth, you ſay, he came back from Holy-Well?

sp.speaker: Wetton.
sp.p: Yes, it was the Sixteenth, upon Fryday, that he came from Holy-Well.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And he ſays, The Ninth of September he came back again from Tixhall to London; and that he ſaw him ſeveral times, in the mean time, at my Lord Aſton's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: So, my Lord, we are paſt one of the Times; and have fixt him at Tixhall upon the Sixteenth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: So, my Lord, we are paſt one of the Times; and have fixt him at Tixhall upon the Sixteenth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We have a couple of Witneſſes more upon this Point, and then we ſhall go on to the Seventeenth; and ſo all along to the Ninth of September.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Thomas Sawyer. (Which was done.) When came Mr. Ireland to Tixhall? Can you tell?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sawyer.
sp.p: He came the Eighth of August to Tixhall, and continued there till the Thirteenth: And then he went away; but whither he went, I cannot tell: But, as I was told, it was to Holy-Well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When did he come to Tixhall again?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sawyer.
sp.p: When my old Lady Aſton came home, which was Fryday the Sixteenth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know when he left Tixhall for good and all?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sawyer.
sp.p: The Ninth of September, my Lord, he went with Sir John Southcoat to go to London.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Can you remember he was there at any time between the Sixteenth of Auguſt, and the Ninth of September?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sawyer.
sp.p: He was once or twice there; but I cannot tell the particular Days.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What Perſwaſion are you of, as to Religion, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sawyer.
sp.p: I am one of the Church of England, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Truth is the ſame in all Perſwaſions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: But we would obviate Mr. Oats his Objection, That they are all Papiſts.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Frances Allen. (Which was done.) Pray, will you give an Account, when you ſaw Mr. Ireland in Staffordſhire?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Allen.
sp.p: He came the Eighth Day of Auguſt to Tixhall, and continued there the Ninth, Tenth, Eleventh, Twelfth, and to the Thirteenth in the Morning, and then he did go to Holy-Well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: She will tell you one particular Circumſtance, how ſhe remembers him about that time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Allen.
sp.p: The Tenth of Auguſt was Saturday; and that which cauſeth me to remember it, is this; There was a Woman, one Sarah Paine, I think her Name was, which teſtifyed at the Tryal, That he was in Town at that time; but he was not: For he was at Tixhall upon the Tenth, which was Saturday; and the Eleventh, which was Sabbath-Day: And I ſaw him in the Chamber thoſe Days.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How came you to know him ſo well?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Allen.
sp.p: I was a Servant to my Lord Aſton, and look't to Mr. Ireland's Chamber, and waſh'd his Linnen; and thoſe Days. I ſaw him in his Chamber.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When he went from Tixhall to Holy-VVell, the 13th. When did he come back again?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Allen.
sp.p: The 16th. day, which was Friday.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did he come afterwards to Tixhall at any time?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Allen.
sp.p: He went away the 17th. and I can tell you by a good token, that he did ſo: For the 17th. I carried his Cloaths into his Chamber, that he was to take with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When did he come again to Tixhall?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Allen.
sp.p: He came ſeveral times, but truly I cannot tell what dayes particularly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, when did he go away for good and all?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Allen.
sp.p: I remember his going away with Sir John Southcoat, but I cannot tell the time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray what Religion are you of.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Allen.
sp.p: I am a Protestant of the Church of England; ſo I was Chriſtened, ſo I have lived, and ſo I hope to dye before you all.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Upon my word, ſhe is very kind, ſhe has a mind to dye before us: 'Tis a ſign ſhe lives a good life, ſhe's ſo ready to die.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: So, my Lord, you ſee that the 17th. of Auguſt, he departed from my Lord Aſtons. Now we ſhall call Mrs. Harwell to give you an account, whether he went on the 17th. Swear Mrs. Jean Harwell. (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Where do you live, Mrs. Harwell?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: I live now in Town, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Where did you live in the Year 78?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: At Wolverhampton.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know Mr. Ireland, he that was Executed?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: Very well, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What time did he come to your Houſe at Wolverhampton?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: The 17. of Auguſt, 1678.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What day of the week was it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harw.
sp.p: Upon Saturday.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: From whence did he ſay he came at that time?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: I do verily believe it was from Tixhall, that he came; I cannot poſitively ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: How long ſtayed he there?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: He came to my Houſe the 17th. of Auguſt. 1678. He ſupped there that night, and I think he lay in my Houſe every night till the 26th. of the ſame month. Upon the 19th. day, after Dinner, I went with him a good part of the Town of Wolverhampton; and upon Friday following, which was the 23d. he went a little way out of Town, to a Fair hard by; and return'd the ſame day; and ſtayed at my Houſe the next day, being Bartholomew-day. The next day being the 25th. being (Sunday) he was at my Houſe, and he ſtayed, as I ſaid, every night, and lay at my Houſe; and went away on Monday, the 26th. of Auguſt. It was to the beſt of my remembrance, in the morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Whether did he ſay he was going, when he went from your Houſe upon the 26th?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: I think to Tixhall, he ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: When did you ſee him again after that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: He returned to me again the 14th. of September following. That night he ſupped at my houſe, and lay there; and he ſtayed at my houſe Thurſday the 5th. of September, Fryday the 6th. and he went away on the 7th. from me for good and all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Whither did he go then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: To Tixhall I think, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Whence did he ſay he came, when he came laſt to your houſe; which was Wedneſday the 4th. of September?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: Then he ſaid, he came from Boſcobel and Black-Ladies, and that way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Can you tell any thing that makes you remember he was at Boſcobel?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: I have ſome Circumſtances, that make me believe, and remember it.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Ay, tell us what they are.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: My Lord, upon Monday the 2d. of September, I heard Mr. Ireland would be at Boſcobel, and I ſaid to my Friend that told me ſo; Sure Mr. Ireland will not be there that night, and I ſo near him. Yes, ſaid ſhe, he will. Then, ſaid I, I will write to him; and ſo I did. And I tell you the 4th. of September, which was Wedneſday, he came to my Houſe, and ſtayed that night, and the two next dayes with me, and went away upon the Saturday after.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You ſay, you did write to him upon the 2d. of September.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: Yes, I did ſo.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What was the occaſion of your writing to him at that time?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: One Madam Dormer, was then in thoſe parts, and he being gon a Viſiting his Friends at Black-Ladies, I writ to him, and deſired him to give her a Viſit for I knew ſhe would be glad to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: He came back to you the 4th. of September, you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Harwell.
sp.p: Yes, he did ſo, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did he own upon the fourth of September that he had received your Letter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: He ſaid he had been at the place, my Lord, but I know not whether he had receiv'd my Letter or no; but I am ſure he waited upon my Lady; for ſhe told me ſo afterwards.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: I deſire to know whether this Gentlewoman was at Ireland's Tryal?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: No, my Lord, but I heard that upon the 17th of December following Mr. Ireland was try'd at the Old Baily for High Treaſon. Upon the 19th, I was inform'd by the Poſt what was ſworn againſt him; and particularly as to this time, which I knew to be falſe: and upon my own Coſt and Charges I ſent an Expreſs away to Town here to a Friend that I knew, upon reading the Letter that was written to me, that Mr. Ireland was falſly accus'd; and by that Expreſs alſo I ſent a Petition, humbly beſeeching his late Majeſty, that we might bring in Witneſſes to prove that Mr. Ireland was in Staffordſhire, when Mr. Oats ſwore he was in Town; and upon that the King ſtaid the Execution about five Weeks. We did hope for a ſecond Tryal, but we could not obtain it; and he was executed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Harwell.
sp.p: I did it at my own Coſt and Charges: for I thought it my duty, if I could, to ſave his Life, knowing that to be falſe which was ſworn againſt him.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: She ſpeaks gravely and ſoberly upon my word.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Withens.
sp.p: So ſhe does indeed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We have abundance of them, my Lord. Swear Mr. William Ruſhton. (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Tell my Lord what you know of Mr. Ireland's being at Mrs. Harwel's in Auguſt 1678, at Wolverhampton.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſhton.
sp.p: My Lord, In the Month of Auguſt 1678, I did ſee Mr. William Ireland at Wolverhampton in the County of Stafford; and it was upon the 18th of Auguſt, and I ſaw him there from the 18th to the 25th, every one of the dayes but one, and that I cannot be poſitive in. He went that day to Litchfield, which was upon the 23th, as I take it, but I cannot be poſitive; but all the reſt of the dayes I did ſee him there once, if not twice or thrice a day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where did he lodge then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſhton.
sp.p: At Mr. Jyfford's, or Mrs. Harwell's.

sp.speaker: Oats.
sp.p: Were you at any of the Tryals of Ireland, or the five Jeſuits, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſhton.
sp.p: No, I was never at none till now.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, what Religion is this Gentleman of, I deſire to know?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſhton.
sp.p: Not of your Worſhip's Religion, Doctor Oates.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But anſwer his Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſhton.
sp.p: I am a Catholick.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: A Roman Catholick he means, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſhton.
sp.p: Yes, I am a Roman Catholick, and a Loyal Subject.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mrs. Katherine Winford (which was done)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mrs. Winford, pray did you ſee Mr. Ireland at Mrs. Harwells, the Year 1678.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Winford.
sp.p: Yes I did Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray tell the Court what you do know of that Matter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Winford.
sp.p: I did hear at Wolver-Hampton, that Mr. Ireland came to Town the 17th of Auguſt, and I did ſee him there the 18th, and I did ſee him there the 19th, and I did ſee him there the 20th, and I ſaw him there upon the 22th, 23th, 24th, and 25th, and that was the laſt time I ſaw him there.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: At Mr. Harwells was it that you ſaw him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Winford.
sp.p: Sometimes at Mrs. Harwells, and ſometimes at my Fathers Houſe, who lived in that Town.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know how ſhe comes to remember thoſe dayes ſo particularly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Winford.
sp.p: I remember them, becauſe St. Bartholomews Day was the 24th of Auguſt, and that was the Saturday after he came to Town; and the firſt day I ſaw him was the Sunday before, and ſo I reckon it to be on thoſe dayes I ſaw him.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Have you any other Queſtions to ask her, Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I have not; She was a Witneſs before at Whitebread's Tryal, and was not believed there.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: We'll make your Remarques by and by, and let them now go on with their Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Then ſwear Mr. William Stanley, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, did you ſee Mr. Ireland at Wolver Hampton, and when.

sp.speaker: Mr. Stanley.
sp.p: Upon the 18th of Auguſt 78. It was Sunday, I ſaw Mr. Ireland in Wolver Hampton in the Morning, and in the Afternoon he was in my own Houſe. Upon Munday the 19th I ſaw him twice that Day at my own Houſe; I poſitively ſpeak that, and I verily believe I did ſee him on Tueſday the 20th, and Wedneſday the 21th; but Thurſday and Friday I cannot ſay I did ſee him thoſe two daies; For he went upon one of them to Litchfield. But upon Saturday and Sunday I am ſure I ſaw him, and two or three times ſome dayes.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Stanley, did you know him before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Stanley.
sp.p: No, I did not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Was you at his Tryal?

sp.speaker: Mr. Stanley.
sp.p: No, I was not.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Were you at the five Jeſuits Tryal?

sp.speaker: Mr. Stanley.
sp.p: No, I was not in London ſince, till the laſt Term.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: What Religion are you of Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Stanley.
sp.p: What Religion are you of Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Nay do not ask Queſtions, but anſwer the Queſtions he asks.

sp.speaker: Mr. Stanley.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Stanley, Pray can you Recollect any Circumſtance how you came to remember that it was ſuch and ſuch Days that you ſaw him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Stanley.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I can.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: What are they, tell them us?

sp.speaker: Mr. Stanley.
sp.p: I buried a Child that Morning, being Sunday the 18th of Auguſt, and he came to my Houſe in the Afternoon, and I entertained him with thoſe things that I had provided for to entertain my Friends at the Funeral. On Munday was a Wake, and the young People went all to the Wake, and left Madam Harwell alone, and ſo ſhe came with him to my Houſe, and I entertained him with the lame kind of entertainment that I did the day before.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: That is a remarkable Circumſtance indeed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mrs. Dorothy Purcell, (which was done.) What ſay you, Mrs. Purcell, when did you ſee Mr. Ireland at Wolverhampton?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Purcell.
sp.p: I ſaw him the 18th, 19th, 20th, 21th, 22th, and 23th, days of Auguſt 1678.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Purcell.
sp.p: At a Friend's Houſe in Wolverhampton.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: How come you to remember thoſe days of the Month?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Purcell.
sp.p: I remember them by particular Circumſtances.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: What are thoſe particular Circumſtances? Let us hear them, How come you to name thoſe very days, the 18th, 19th, and ſo on?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Purcell.
sp.p: I can remember it as well as any thing in the World.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire, my Lord, that ſhe may tell how ſhe does remember it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Purcell.
sp.p: That's enough, and as much as need to be ſaid, I remember very well.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: But I deſire to know how you come to Remember it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Purcell.
sp.p: I remember it, I tell you, very well; And I do affirm I ſaw him 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: But you do not tell what Circumſtances you remembed in by.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Purcell.
sp.p: No, there is no need of it, I am ſure I ſaw him there. then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Tell him ſome Circumſtances.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Purcell.
sp.p: Thoſe were the days before Bartholomew Eve.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, Is this any thing of Evidence?

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: The Jury hears it, and they will Conſider of it.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: What Religion are you of Mrs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Purcel.
sp.p: Muſt I tell what Religion I am of.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Yes, anſwer his Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I dare ſay ſhe is a Papiſt, ſhe need not trouble her Head to anſwer it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Scot, (which was done.) Were you at Wolverhampton when Mr. Ireland was there.

sp.speaker: Mr Scott.
sp.p: Yes, I was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you do any Service for him there?

sp.speaker: Scott.
sp.p: I look'd to his Horſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When did he come thither, do you remember?

sp.speaker: Scott.
sp.p: I cannot tell juſt the time that he came in.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What day of the Week was it that he came thither?

sp.speaker: Scott.
sp.p: It was of a Saturday.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What Month was it.

sp.speaker: Scott.
sp.p: I cannot tell very well what Month it was; It was in Auguſt I think.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How long did he continue there?

sp.speaker: Scott.
sp.p: The ſpace of a fortnight off and on.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Is that Evidence, my Lord, that he has delivered?

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: It is but very ſmall Evidence. It is only Circumſtantial to confirm the other Teſtimony.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How long was it before Ireland was tryed and executed, can you tell that?

sp.speaker: Scott.
sp.p: No, I know nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then ſwear Mr. John Stamford, (which was done)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Ireland at VVolverhampton, and when was it I pray you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Stamford.
sp.p: My Lord, in the year 1675, I was ſent beyond Sea to St. Omers, to fetch over two young Gentlemen that were Students there; And there I became acquainted with Mr. Ireland, who was then Procurator of the Jeſuits at St. Omers. And in Auguſt 78. I did ſee him in VVolverhampton, upon the Sunday after the Aſſumption of our Lady; which was the 15th of Auguſt, he came to ſee me, and I ſaw him there that Day.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: What day of the month is the Aſſumption of our Lady?

sp.speaker: Mr. Stamford.
sp.p: That is alwayes the 15th of Auguſt, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How often did you ſee him there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Stamford.
sp.p: I ſaw him Sunday and Munday, and till that ſeven Night, I ſaw him every day in that Week but one, when he went to Litchfield.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know how he comes to remember that it was at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: He tells you a Reaſon for it, becauſe it fell out to be upon the Sunday after the Aſſumption of our Lady, which is alwayes the 15th of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, he ſayes he came acquainted with Mr. Ireland at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Yes, he ſays, that was in the year 1675.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire to know, my Lord, what Buſineſs he had there.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: He tells you, he went to fetch over two young men that were Students there.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, I deſire to know what Religion he is of.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: What Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Stamford.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire to know what his Profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Stamford.
sp.p: I am a younger Brother, of a good and loyal Family as any of the County of Stafford, and that ſuffered as much as any for the late King.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I believe if it were looked into he is ſomewhat elſe beſides a younger Brother.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, he ſays he is of a Loyal Family.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: I am ſure there is ſuch a Family in that County that were great ſufferers for King Charles the Firſt, and the late King; and were very inſtrumental in Services for the late King, at his eſcape from Worcester; But whether he be of that Family or no I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Stamford.
sp.p: The Doctor thinks I am a Jeſuite, but I'll aſſure him I have Wife and Children.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Oates was about to have made him a Prieſt, but it ſeems he hath a Wife and Children, and ſo it is out of danger.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray ſwear Mrs. Katherine Fowler. (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Ireland, Mrs. Fowler, at Wolverhampton, in 1678?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fowler.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When was it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fowler.
sp.p: I did ſee him on Saturday the 17th of Auguſt at Wolverhampton, he came that day to my Mothers Houſe, where I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How long did he ſtay there?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fowler.
sp.p: Till the 27th, which was Munday was Sevennight after, I was in his Company every day in that time unleſs it were Friday (which day they ſay he went to Litchfield to the Fair.)

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Is Mrs. Harwell your Mother?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fowler.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, ſhe is, and I lived at that time with my Mother.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: How do you remember this, have you any Tokens that you can give us, why you remember it was then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fowler.
sp.p: My Lord, I recollected my ſelf after Mr. Ireland's Tryal, in which Mr. Oates Swore that he was hear in Town between the 8th and 12th of Auguſt, that that was the very Month that Mr. Ireland was in Wolverhampton, and thereupon I concluded that Mr. Oates had not Sworn true by that Recollection when it was freſh in my memory, being within half a year after.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Madam, are you Mrs. Harwells Daughter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fowler.
sp.p: Yes, I am ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Did you not know one Mr Jenniſon?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fowler.
sp.p: Which Jenniſon?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Mr. Robert Jenniſon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fowler.
sp.p: Yes, I do know him.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Are you not a kin to him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fowler.
sp.p: Yes, but I am ſorry to own I have ſuch a Relation.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Gifford, (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Ireland in Stafford-ſhire, and when; I pray you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gifford.
sp.p: I ſaw him there at Wolverhampton the 17th of Auguſt 1678, and he continued there till the 26th. I ſaw him there every day.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, be pleaſed to ask this Gentleman whether he were at the Tryal of Ireland.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gifford.
sp.p: No, I was not in Court nor examined as a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Were you at the Tryal of the five Jeſuites, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gifford.
sp.p: I was there, but was not examined.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Was it every day, ſay you, that you ſaw him at Wolverhampton?

sp.speaker: Mr. Gifford.
sp.p: Every day.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: They ſay, he was one day out of Town at Litchfield.

sp.speaker: Mr. Gifford.
sp.p: He was out of Town that day, but I ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mrs. Elizabeth Gifford, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: You hear the Queſtion, did you ſee Mr. Ireland in Stafford-ſhire in 78. and when?

sp.speaker: Mrs. E. Gifford.
sp.p: Mr. Ireland came to Wolverhampton the 17th of Auguſt, and continued there till the 26th.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How do you remember it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gifford.
sp.p: By a Wake that was juſt hard by, that was at that time; and he came to my Uncles Houſe upon the Sunday following the Aſſumption of our Lady.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee him every day till the 26th?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gifford.
sp.p: I remember I did ſee him every day, but two days, that I was abroad at the Wake.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know whether She was examined at any of the former Tryals.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gifford.
sp.p: Yes, at the five Jeſuites Tryal, I was.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Were you not at Ireland's Tryal?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gifford.
sp.p: No, I was not.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: There was one Gifford examined there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mrs. Elizabeth Keeling; (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Ireland at Wolverhampton, and when?

sp.speaker: Keeling.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I did ſee Mr. Ireland at Wolverhampton.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray tell when it was.

sp.speaker: Keeling.
sp.p: It was the 17th of Auguſt he came to my Miſtreſſes Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: What Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Keeling.
sp.p: Auguſt before the Plot.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice
sp.p: Who was your Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Keeling.
sp.p: Mrs. Harewell, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: How long did he continue there?

sp.speaker: Keeling.
sp.p: He came on the Saturday, and I ſaw him there till the Monday. When I was ſent for to my Mothers Burying I left him and Madam Dormer at Dinner, and came back on the Thurſday. And in his Chamber I heard him diſcourſe, but I did not ſee him. Upon the Friday he went abroad, and returned again that Night. Upon the Saturday I faw him, and he continued there till Monday Morning, and then he went away, and returned on Wedneſday the 4th of September, and ſtayed till Saturday the 7th; and then went away from VVolverhampton.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire to know what Religion this Woman is of.

sp.speaker: Keeling.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick, God be thanked.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mrs. Keeling, When did Mr. Ireland return again do you ſay, after he went firſt to Wolverhampton?

sp.speaker: Keeling.
sp.p: It was the Wedneſday ſeven night after Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: That was the 4th of September.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice,
sp.p: How long ſtayed he there then?

sp.speaker: Keeling.
sp.p: Till Saturday in the Forenoon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Whither did he ſay he was going then?

sp.speaker: Keeling.
sp.p: He ſaid he went to Bellamour to Dinner.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Did you ſee him at any time after?

sp.speaker: Keeling.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I ſaw him no more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then ſwear Mr. Richardſon, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Sir will you give an Account when you ſaw Mr. Ireland, and where in the year 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Richardſon.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſaw a Gentleman that I was informed was Mr. Ireland, at Wolverhampton, at a Wake; which was Monday the 19th of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where did he lodg?

sp.speaker: Mr. Richardſon.
sp.p: At Mrs. Harwells.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What are you a Tradeſman?

sp.speaker: Mr. Richardſon.
sp.p: Yes, an Apothecary in Wolverhampton.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: How many days did you ſee him at Wolverhampton.

sp.speaker: Mr. Richardſon.
sp.p: I ſaw him onely one day in the Market-place.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: You did not know Mr. Ireland before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Richardſon.
sp.p: But I was inform'd that was he.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: What became of that Ireland that you were informed was at Wolverhampton then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Richardſon.
sp.p: I heard preſently after that, upon Mr. Oates's Plot, he was ſecured and Executed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What Religion are you of, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Richardſon.
sp.p: I am of the Church of England.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, I would ask you this Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Richardſon.
sp.p: As many Queſtions as you pleaſe, Mr. Oates.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Who told you it was Mr. Ireland?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: When was it ſhe told you it was Ireland?

sp.speaker: Mr. Richardſon.
sp.p: To the beſt of my Remembrance, it was before he was apprehended as a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: He is uncertain when he was told ſo.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, make what Advantage you can of it by and by.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mrs. Eleanor Graves, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Miſtriſs did you ſee Mr. Ireland at VVolverhampton at any time?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Graves.
sp.p: Yes, I did my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: When was it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Graves.
sp.p: The firſt time was ſix years ago, in Auguſt it is now going on ſeven years ſince.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What time in Auguſt was it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Graves.
sp.p: The firſt day was the 20th, or 21th, I am ſure I ſaw him upon the 22th; for I din'd with him, and was with him all the Afternoon; and ſup'd with him. Upon the 23th we went to Litchfield together, which was Bartholomew Eve. And I ſaw him the 25th, which was Sunday after.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Are you ſure it is the Ireland we are now ſpeaking of?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Graves.
sp.p: They ſaid it was the ſame Mr. Ireland that was executed. They call'd him ſo.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Nay, there is no great doubt, but only for Mr. Oates's Satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: At whoſe Houſe did he lye at VVolverhampton?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Graves.
sp.p: At Mrs. Harwells.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where was it you ſup'd with him, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Graves.
sp.p: He din'd and ſup'd at a Relations Houſe of mine.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: Who was that? Name him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Graves.
sp.p: It was at my Uncle VVinfords.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you go along with him to Litchfield do you ſay on the 23th?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Graves.
sp.p: Yes, and ſo did my Uncle; and at Night we came back together.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: What Religion are you of Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Graves.
sp.p: I am of the Church of England.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to ask her, how did ſhe know it was the ſame Ireland that was tryed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Graves.
sp.p: It was the ſame Ireland that they ſaid was afterwards executed. I know no more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Did you go back with him to Mrs. Harwells from Litchfield?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Graves.
sp.p: I did, to my Uncle VVinfords Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Now we come, my Lord, to another Period of time, which is from the 26th of Auguſt, to the 29th; and for that we firſt call Sir Thomas VVhitegrave: who is a Juſtice of the Peace, and a worthy Gentleman; a Member of the Church of England in that County. Swear him, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Sir Thomas, will you be pleaſed to give the Court an account whether you ſaw Mr. Ireland in Staffordſhire, 1678, and what time it was?

sp.speaker: Sir Thomas Whitegrave.
sp.p: I ſaw Mr. Ireland upon the 29th of Auguſt before the Popiſh Plot; It was upon a Thurſday in the Afternoon upon Tixhal Bowling green; and I diſcourſed with him; he told me he was to go home that Night with Sir James Simmons, and Mr. Heveningham. They told me afterwards he went on Saturday to Hilderſham, and went thence on Monday following towards Boſcobel; Sometime after that, a Rumor came down that Mr. Ireland was accuſed with others, of being in a Plot of the Papiſts; and my ſelf and ſome others that were in Commiſſion for the Peace in that County, did reflect upon the time that Ireland was in the Country, and we were a little diſturbed, becauſe he had been at particular Places among our Neighbours, whom we knew to be Catholicks.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Can you remember no day but that one, Sir Thomas?

sp.speaker: Sir Thomas Whitegrave.
sp.p: Only the 29th I ſaw him there, and diſcours'd with him; and afterwards there was Word ſent to me, to deſire me that I would come up to London at his Tryal.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: And did you come up, Sir Thomas?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Whitegrave.
sp.p: No, I did not; I had no Subpaena: and being a Juſtice of the Peace, I did not think fit to leave the Country at that time without a Subpaena.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know of this Gentleman, how long he had been acquainted with Mr. Ireland.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Whitegrave.
sp.p: I Never ſaw him before, nor ſince.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: He goes no further then the 20th.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: No, my Lord, he does not. Then ſwear Mr. William Fowler, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray will you give an Account when you ſaw Mr. Ireland, and where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fowler.
sp.p: I ſaw Mr. Ireland upon the 27th of Auguſt 78. in Staffordſhire, at a Horſe Race at Etching-hill. The Race was run between Sir Henry Gough, and Captain Cherwine.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee him any other Day in that Month?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fowler.
sp.p: Yes, the 29th of Auguſt I ſaw him at Tixhall Bowling-green.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: When elſe did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fowler.
sp.p: I ſaw him the 10th of Auguſt before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Where, at Tixhall, at my Lord Aſton's Houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember Sir Thomas Whitegrave was upon the Bowling-green the 27th of Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fowler.
sp.p: Yes, he was, and did diſcourſe with Mr. Ireland there.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: What became of Mr. Ireland afterwards?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fowler.
sp.p: He went about the Country for ſome time, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: Was it the ſame Ireland that was executed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fowler.
sp.p: Yes, it was the ſame.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: You ſay you ſaw him the 29th, at Tixhall Bowling green?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fowler.
sp.p: Yes, I did ſo.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: When you heard he was taken up for the Plot, What did they ſay whither he went at that Time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fowler.
sp.p: I think he went to Mr. Heveningams, or thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I would fain know this Gentlemans Religion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fowler.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſtice.
sp.p: We ask it only becauſe Mr. Oates deſires to be ſatisfied in that point.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray ſwear Mr. Howard, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: What time in Auguſt. 78, did you ſee Mr. Ireland in Staffordſhire, and where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Howard.
sp.p: I came out of Shropſhire upon the 27th of Auguſt, to the Horſe-race at Etching-hill; and there I ſaw this Mr. Ireland upon the 28th. I dined at one Mr. Herbert Aſtons Houſe at Bellamore, and there I ſaw him again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What other time did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Howard.
sp.p: Never any other time.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: How does he know it was the ſame Mr. Ireland?

sp.speaker: Mr. Howard.
sp.p: I came up to Town ſoon after, and they told me that knew him, that it was the ſame Ireland that ſuffer'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Drayton, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Where did you ſee Mr. Ireland?

sp.speaker: Mr. Drayton.
sp.p: At Etching-hill Race.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What day was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Drayton.
sp.p: That was the 27th of Auguſt, 1678.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When did you ſee him after?

sp.speaker: Mr. Drayton.
sp.p: The next day following I did not ſee him; but the Thurſday following I ſaw him at Tixhall, and he went home with Mr. Heveningham to Aſton, and I ſaw him on Friday, he was with us there; and went a fiſhing, and we catch'd a great Pike of yard long; which was not ordinary with us. Upon the 31th, which was Saturday, my Maſter went to kill a Buck in the Park, and Mr. Ireland went along with him; and they went to a little Village hard by, and there I parted with him, and did ſee him no more that day. Mr. Gerrard of Hilderſham was to meet my Maſter a hunting, but he was ſick, and did not. Then upon Sunday the firſt of September, I was ſent to ſee Mr. Gerrard of Hilderſham, and there I ſaw Mr. Ireland.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Who was your Maſter pray you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Drayton.
sp.p: This Lord Gerrard of Bromeleys Father.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: He was accuſed by Dugdale of the Plot, and dyed afterwards in Newgate.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray ask Mr. Drayton what Religion he is of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Drayton.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Sir James Simmons, (which was done)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr. Ireland, Sir James?

sp.speaker: Sir J. Simmons.
sp.p: Upon the Tueſday the 27th of Auguſt 78. I remember very well, I ſaw Mr. Ireland at the Horſe-race at Etching-hill, between Sir Henry Gough, and Mr. Chetwin; and I remember particularly, that Sir Henry Gough's Horſe diſtanc'd him. I did not ſee him before he came to the Inn, but there we met, and drank together. And Thurſday the 29th of Auguſt, being at Tixhall Bowling-green, Mr. Ireland was there, and came home with my Father Heveningham and me, and ſome Gentlemen in the Country: and came to Aſton, and ſtay'd there that Night. I remember the next day was Pancraſs Fair, and I went to the Fair, and did not come home.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What day of the Month is that Fair uſually kept?

sp.speaker: Sir J. Simmons.
sp.p: It is an unconſtant time; now and then in September, now and then in Auguſt; and that year we had a Subſcription to get it regulated to a certain day.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you ſee him after?

sp.speaker: Sir J. Simmons.
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot ſwear to the Saturday, becauſe I cannot ſo well tell whether I came back from the Fair on Friday Night, I think I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Green, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know Mr. Ireland?

sp.speaker: Mr. Green.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: When did you ſee him in 78?

sp.speaker: Mr. Green.
sp.p: The firſt time was Etching-hill Race, the 27th of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: What other dayes do you remember?

sp.speaker: Mr. Green.
sp.p: Thurſday the 29th, I ſaw him; I belong to Sir James Simmons, and Mr. Ireland came home with him, and ſome other Gentlemen to Mr. Heveningham's at Aſton; and was a ſetting with him on Friday the 30th in the Afternoon. And Saturday the 31th, he was a hunting with Mr. Gerrard. Nay, more then that, I ſaw him drawn on the Sledg, but not executed. And that was the ſame man that was there at that time.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: What Religion is this Gentleman of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Green.
sp.p: I was ever a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Pray were they a fiſhing that Day?

sp.speaker: Mr. Green.
sp.p: In the Morning he was, and they got a great Pike; I ſaw the Pike, and did eat part of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Fallas, (which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr. Ireland, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fallas.
sp.p: Upon the Thurſday after Sir Henry Gough's race, which was Thurſday the 29th of Auguſt; Mr. Ireland came to Mr. Heveninghams, and I look'd to his Horſe there. Upon Friday Morning they went a fiſhing, and got a great Pike; and I did ſee them go out a ſetting after Dinner, he and Mr. Green, with my Lady and the Keeper; and I ſaw him come in again. And I ſaw him drink a Glaſs of Table Beer in the Hall. Upon Saturday Morning, which was the 31th of Auguſt, they went a hunting in Mr. Gerrards Park, and kill'd a Buck; and afterwards my Maſter asked him to go home with him again, but he would not: For he ſaid he muſt go to Mr. Lowes at four, and we parted at three. And I came here, and ſaw him executed; but while he was at my Maſters Houſe, his Horſe was never out of the Stable, but I brought it to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When did you ſee him executed?

sp.speaker: Fallas.
sp.p: It was the 24th of January afterwards, I think.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: What Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Fallas.
sp.p: I am for the Church of England, a Proteſtant, I alwayes was ſo.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, ask him when he was acquainted with Mr. Ireland?

sp.speaker: Fallas.
sp.p: The firſt time was the 29th of Auguſt, when he came to my Maſters Houſe.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: That does not come to my time, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But it comes very cloſe to it; it reaches to the 31th of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It is within a day of you, upon my word.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: And I'll tell your Lordſhip what is yet more conſiderable; this place is an hundred and twenty miles from London: but we ſhall not leave him there.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: I deſire to know whoſe Servant he is.

sp.speaker: Fallas.
sp.p: I am a Servant to Mr. Heveningham, and I ſerve the King; I come to teſtifie the Truth. I was here before, but then we muſt not be heard; all the cry was againſt us, that we were Rogues, and muſt be knockt on the head.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you here at any of the Tryals.

sp.speaker: Fallas.
sp.p: I was at the Council-Table, and there I was in great danger of being knockt on the head.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Would they have knockt him on the head at the Council-Table, does he ſay?

sp.speaker: Fallas.
sp.p: I have been in the Room by the Council-Table, where they have cryed, Knock them down, hang them Rogues; do they come to be Witneſſes againſt the Saviour of the World? And they came about me there, and asked me if I knew any of them, or was of their company? And I was glad to ſay I came thither about a Suit of Law I had with a Brother of mine; and then they pitied me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Now we have brought him, my Lord, every night where he lodged from the 3d of Auguſt to the 31th.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And then we ſhall prove that he went to Mr. Gerrards at Hilderſome that they ſpeak of; there he was the 31th and 32th—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How, Mr. Attorney, the 32th? I doubt you will hardly be able to tell us where he was that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: The Firſt of September I mean, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Aye, we underſtand you very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. John Proctor. (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr. Ireland, in 78?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: I ſaw him the 31th of Auguſt 78.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: At Fulford.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: At whoſe Houſe.

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: At Mr. Lowes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: That was the place the other Witneſs ſaid Ireland told him he was to be at Four of the Clock, and therefore went away at Three.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When did you ſee him afterwards?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: I ſaw him the next day, the 1ſt of September.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: At Eſquire Gerrards.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How far is that from Mr. Lowes?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: It is a mile and a half.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee him afterwards?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: Not there I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: I am a Proteſtant.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did you hear became of that Ireland afterwards?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: I ſaw him Executed at Tyburn afterwards, and it was the ſame Man.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where did you live then?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: I lived at Fulford then.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What, with Mr. Lowe?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: It ſeems he was a Servant to a Papiſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What then, what of that?

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire you would ask him whether he ever ſaw Ireland before the 31th of Auguſt which he ſpeakes of?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you are ſure it was the ſame man you ſaw Executed?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: Yes, I am ſure of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: What Circumſtance can you tell that he was the Firſt of September at Mr. Gerrards?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: I went to dinner thither that day: I Rode before Madam Brooke.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What day of the Week was that Firſt of September?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: It was upon a Sunday, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was that about Pancraſs-Fair-time?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: He can tell you another circumſtance how he comes to remember him at Mr. Lowes the 31th of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Aye, by what Token do you remember that he was there the 31th of Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: I went that day to 〈…〉 pay ſome Money, and came home again in the Afternoon; and juſt as I came in, he came thither.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: How does he ſay he knows him to be the ſame Man?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He has told you twice he ſaw him Executed.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: What Religion is he of does he ſay?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He is a Proteſtant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then Swear Mr. John King. (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray do you acquaint the Court and the Jury where you ſaw Mr. Ireland, and when.

sp.speaker: Mr. King.
sp.p: I ſaw Mr. Ireland at Mr. Gerrards of Hilderſome the Firſt of September that year that the Plot broke out, which was in the year 78. There I ſaw him on Sunday; there he ſtayed all night, and ſo did I; and on Monday-morning I went to Mrs. Cromptons where I liv'd, and he came thither to Millage as ſoon as I, which is within a mile of Hilderſome, and dined there the ſame day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How far is that from London, pray you?

sp.speaker: Mr. King.
sp.p: An hundred and ten miles.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And he was there at Dinner, you ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. King.
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long was it before Dinner was done?

sp.speaker: Mr. King.
sp.p: I believe he might go thence about Two of the Clock.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where did he ſay he deſigned to go then?

sp.speaker: Mr. King.
sp.p: He deſigned to go to Boſcobel that night.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you remember any body elſe was at Mr. Gerrards then when you ſaw him?

sp.speaker: Mr. King.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Jerman Drayton was at Hilderſome at that time.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: Pray, what Religion is this Gentleman of?

sp.speaker: Mr. King.
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick, Mr. Oates.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Swear Mr. Francis Lee. (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, tell my Lord and the Jury where you ſaw Mr. Ireland, and when.

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.p: I was a Servant to Mr. Gerrard, and Mr. Ireland upon Saturday-night came to my Maſters Houſe, and ſtayed all night and all day on Sunday, and went away on Munday to Millage.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time and what year was it?

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.p: It was in 78; but I am not certain of the day of the Month: It was on a Saturday he came, and I have Witneſſes to prove I was there at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Month was it?

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.p: It was in Auguſt, as I think, the laſt day, but I am not certain. And he went on Monday to Millage, and there dined at Mrs. Cromptons; and from thence he went to Pancraſs, and thence he did go to Boſcobel, and ſtayed all night there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: That was the Second of September.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How do you know he went to theſe places?

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.p: I was told ſo.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know how long this man was acquainted with Ireland before?

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.p: I never ſaw him but at that time.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: How does he know it is the ſame man then?

sp.speaker: Mr. King.
sp.p: Here is a man that ſaw me with him, and was preſent at Irelands Execution.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who is that, Proctor?

sp.speaker: Mr. King.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then call Proctor again, (who came in again) Who went along with you to Dinner on Munday?

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.p: My Lord, he did ſee me at Hilderſome at Mr. Gerrards.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you, Proctor, was this Gentleman there at that time?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I did ſee him there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was that the ſame man that was Executed, which you ſaw at Mr. Gerrards?

sp.speaker: Proctor.
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you dine with Mr. Ireland on Munday at Mrs. Cromptons?

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I did, and went afterwards with him to Pancraſs, and ſtayed there two hours, and then he went to Boſcobel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: There are the two days gone which Mr. Oates ſwore to, and in which he was ſo poſitive that it was either the firſt or ſecond of September.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then Swear Mr. Biddolph. (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, when did you ſee Mr. Ireland, and where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Biddolph.
sp.p: My Lord, I was in Staffordſhire the latter end of Auguſt, and the beginning of September, and I was at Mrs. Cromptons Houſe, which is my Aunt, the Second of September, being Munday, where I ſaw Mr. Ireland and dined with him that day; and after dinner he went with Mr. Gerrard's Son who was to go to School to Boſcobel: And I will give your Lordſhip a particular circumſtance that may ſatisfie you that I am not miſtaken in the time: As I came thorough Northamptonſhire that Summer, I was at my Lord Cullens, and he deſired me to be at a Horſe-Race at Newton-Slade, where there is a Plate always R •… n for upon the firſt Thurſday in September, and that year it was the 5th of September. Now when I dined at my Aunt Cromptons, ſhe would have had me ſtaid all night at her Houſe, but I excuſed my ſelf, and told her I had promiſed to come to my Lord Cullen to be at the Race, and I muſt needs be there before, to be as good as my word to my Lord; and therefore I went away to Pancraſs, and ſo on my Journey otherwiſe I had ſtayed with my Aunt all night: And I am ſure this was Munday before this Horſe-Race.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, this Gentleman ſpeaks to no year particularly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Biddolph.
sp.p: It was in 1678, the year before Mr. Oates's Plot broke out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Now we will call Mrs. Crompton: Swear her. (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, when did you ſee Mr. Ireland, Mrs. Crompton?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Crompton.
sp.p: He was at my Houſe at Millage in Staffordſhire at Dinner, the ſame day that my Nephew Biddolph did dine there: As for the day of the Month I cannot ſo well tell it, becauſe when my Friends dine with me, I do not uſe to note down the day particularly; but it was, I remember, a pretty remarkable time, for it was about Pancraſs-Fair. Mr. Gerrard of Hilderſome came with him, and Mr. Ireland being a Stranger, I asked who he was, and they told me it was Mr. Ireland: He never was at my Houſe before nor after; he was a meer Stranger to me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What day was it ſay you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Crompton.
sp.p: It was the ſame day my Nephew Biddolph dined there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was it Munday the ſecond of September, do you remember?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: He ſays he was at her Houſe at Millage that day, and ſhe ſays it was the ſame day he dined there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Crompton.
sp.p: But I never note down the particular days when my Friends dine with me, except I had particular occaſion to do it, as I had none at this time.

sp.speaker: Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know what Religion this old Gentlewoman is of.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Crompton,
sp.p: I am a Roman Catholick, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mrs. Palmer. (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Mrs. Palmer, where did you ſee Mr. Ireland?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Palmer.
sp.p: I was at dinner at Mrs. Cromptons at Millage, where there was a Gentleman called Mr. Ireland that did dine there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Palmer
sp.p: I cannot tell truly what day it was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was there beſides you at dinner that day?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Palmer
sp.p: 'Tis ſo long ſince I cannot remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was Mr. Biddolph there?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Palmer.
sp.p: Not that I remember, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you bring her for, Mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: She dined there that day it ſeems; but if ſhe cannot remember it, I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But theſe kind of Witneſſes do but ſlack your proof.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I think we do ever do our Buſineſs indeed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We have one Witneſs more to this point, and that is Mrs. Mary Holmes; Swear her. (Which was done.) Where did you ſee Mr. Ireland in the year 78.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Holmes
sp.p: I ſaw him at Millage, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Holmes.
sp.p: The firſt or the beginning of September, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: What day of the week was it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Holmes.
sp.p: Munday.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You have proof enough of this, Mr. Attorney General.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Truly, I think ſo, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Pray ſwear Mrs. Eſther Gifford. (Which was done.) Mrs. Gifford, when did you ſee Mr. Ireland?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gifford.
sp.p: Upon the ſecond of September 78 I ſaw Mr. Ireland, above a hundred miles from this place.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gifford.
sp.p: At Pancraſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: What time of the day was it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gifford.
sp.p: In the Afternoon about Four or Five a Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Did he ſtay there all night?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gifford.
sp.p: I cannot tell indeed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Pendrel. (Which was done.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, we are come to the ſecond of September in the Evening; we ſhall prove where he was that night and the third, and then we ſhall return to the fourth of September, when Mrs. Harwel ſwears he came back to Wolverhampton.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hanſes.
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr. Ireland, Mr. Pendrel?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pendrel.
sp.p: I ſaw him upon the ſecond of September.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pendrel.
sp.p: At Boſcobel at my Houſe, there he lodged with me that night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: In what year was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pendrel.
sp.p: In the year 1678.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was it the September before the Plot, and before Mr. Ireland was Executed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pendrel.
